title: Andy Murray fights back in Shanghai to down Londero and book Fognini clash
text:
Andy Murray set up a clash with Fabio Fognini (Picture: Getty Images)

Andy Murray fought back from a set down to beat Juan Ignacio Londero and book his spot in the second round of the Shanghai Masters.

Murray, 32, maintained his 100% record in the first round of events in China with a 2-6 6-2 6-3 win over the Argentine qualifier in two hours and 13 minutes and once again displayed tremendous battling qualities as he set up a meeting with Italian 10th seed Fabio Fognini.

It was a thoroughly entertaining watch and not only for the tennis. An animated Murray let out several high-decibel roars and chuntered aggressively to himself and in the direction of his team throughout, while Londero was resigned to slapping himself around the face in fury at his failure to break down the three-time Grand Slam champion.

Londero was beaten (Picture: Getty Images)

On a three-match losing streak heading into Shanghai, Londero seemingly found his groove coming through qualifying and adapted far quicker to the conditions than the British No. 6, in what was his first appearance at this Masters 1000 event since he won a third title there in 2016.

For much of the first set Londero struck a clean ball – hitting 18 winners in total – but Murray was largely the architect of his own downfall, with his forehand misfiring.

But as Londero’s level dipped, Murray’s rose. He tidied up his game in the second set – creating multiple break point chances in each return game – and soon levelled.

The third and final set was by far the most competitive – with both finally simultaneously operating at a high level – but a pumped up Murray was ultimately the victor.

Murray was put under pressure early on by his Argentine opponent and was forced to save two break points in a 14-minute opening game with aces – first down the T and then out wide – while a third saw Londero fire narrowly wide before Murray held.

Three break point chances came and went for Murray – whose forehand was spluttering errors – in the fourth game of the match and they came back to bite him in the fifth, with his opponent breaking after 35 minutes.

Andy Murray struggled early on (Picture: Getty)

His erratic forehand cost him dearly at 40-0 up in the seventh game. With the court at his mercy, Murray sent the ball long before serving two double faults on his way to falling a double break and 5-2 behind.

With his 18th winner of the set, Londero wrapped up a thoroughly deserved 1-0 lead with 49 minutes on the clock.

Murray responded well early in the second, winning four points in a row from 40-15 down to break before holding for a 3-0 lead just beyond the hour mark.

Londero recovered from 15-40 down in his next two service games to hold but ultimately couldn’t keep a resurrgent Murray down, with the Briton securing the set with a double break.

A sliced backhand dumped into the net saw Londero broken to love to fall 3-1 down in the decider but he hit back with a crisp forehand return winner in the next game, much to the frustration of an expletive-spitting Murray.

At the change of ends, he repeatedly aimed repetitive questions of ‘yes or no?’ – yes or no to what is not exactly clear – with a sarcastic look on his face in the direction of his team but a stunning forehand winner on the run left him roaring with joy as he broke once more for a 4-2 lead.

After his opponent slapped himeslf around the face repeatedly at the next change of ends, Murray was soon over the line and joined compatriot Cam Norrie in the second round.

Both have outside chances of replacing Kyle Edmund as British No. 1 this week. Murray would need the title.
